author: bluecb33
title: Things improved once I was with CGL
body:
I had a situational crisis in 2018. This resulted in me having a criminal conviction and turning to alcohol to numb the pain.  
It started off small and snowballed until it was out of control. During this time I lost two jobs, spent 5 days in the Royal Edinburgh Hospital and had multiple suicide attempts. After the last attempt I self-referred to CGL. The alcohol gave me relief for a very short period and was quickly followed by shame, self-loathing and disgust. It very nearly cost me my family.  
Once I was in the system with CGL things improved. I attended meetings when I could and was eventually started on medication. I’ve been sober since July 2021. I’ve been discharged to the care of my GP now with the understanding I can reach out to CGL should I start to struggle.  
My intention over the coming months is to find a group to attend so I have a support network in place if/when I need it. It would have been great for me if there was a meeting outwith office hours as I am now back working.

title: Not good
body: I have been diagnosed with complex PTSD and have just been left out in the cold as for my doctors unless I phone them up about how I'm doing on my meds there is no follow up I have been waiting for the trauma team since the above date and am still suffering with my mental health it's the first time I've asked for help with this I am now 60 years old and have always managed myself with drugs then work but now I'm too broken to be working like I have at the end of my tether to be honest.

readBy.name: Midlands Partnership NHS Foundation Trust o

author: coinrt78
title: Fantastic care
body: Absolutely fantastic care and compassion for my daughter getting her 2nd covid jab at the CAH allergy clinic. Brenda the nurse administering the injection was caring and reassuring and Denise who managed the times and clinic and rang me back to check on my daughter a few days afterwards was amazingly helpful, caring and considerate. First class treatment.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Natbs79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Absolutely no problems
body:
My Daisy Hill Hospital experience began in DAU after I developed chest pain. My time here was very good. All the staff were very very good as well.  
Up on the Female Surgical Ward it has again been good. I have had absolutely no problems with the staff - they have all been excellent.  
I have nothing to suggest regarding improvements.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Natbs79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff all really lovely
body:
I came to the Emergency Department at Daisy Hill where I was diagnosed with inflammation of the kidney. I had a bit of a wait in A&E - probably around 6 hours. The staff were all very nice during this time however.  
I was then moved up to the Female Surgical Ward. It has been very good up here and all the staff have been really lovely. Lisa has been particularly good.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Essec
title: Impossible to get an appointment
body: A sort of miserable resignation- that's how it's going to be. Just can't seem to get to see anyone for an appointment any more, and will just have to live with it, the pains that are not getting any better. But alongside that a sense that this is not right - it's not what the NHS, 'our NHS ' is supposed to be about. How many people who in some really bad way are just giving up?! This is not acceptable!

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The pleasure of meeting staff
body: My care on the ward has been absolutely excellent so far. I cannot complain about a single member of staff that I have had the absolute pleasure of dealing with. They have all been so helpful and caring from the sisters and doctors to the domestics and cleaners. At the start I did not enjoy the food however after being advised by the dietician to eat more regularly, I have started to accept it. I always get enough food, which is good as I am not hungry. Everything is always clean and the cleaners will always clean anything that I ask them too. I was very uncomfortable at the start of my treatment as I had catheters in to help with going to the toilet. These were necessary however, and it was explained to me why they were used. This, like all of my treatment plan was very well explained to me which is something I am grateful for. In my previous ward when I was very unwell I lost a bible and a tale given to me by the Chaplin, however I am not that worried about these items and understand things may have been misplaced.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Saz1224
title: kind and supportive care
body: I recently experienced really kind and supportive care in the early pregnancy unit at stepping hill. I was scanned to find out if everything was ok at 6.5 weeks pregnant and the team were very reassuring, and calmed my anxiety.

author: ahcsim
title: My mother having a fall and then being diagnosed with a terminal illness - DECS-A
body: Our 85 year old mother had a fall and fractured her hip in December 2021. Upon discharge it became very apparent something was not right with mum. She was confused, generally unaware of the here and now, her mobility deteriorated, she became incontinent and she was sleeping a lot. We struggled badly to get anyone to take a holistic view of mum's health (she had other medical issues previously diagnosed). After weeks of struggles, we were eventually referred to DECS-A (Dundee Enhanced Community Support Acute Team) and that's our best experience of the NHS to date. The DECS-A team - every member - has been outstanding. They have been attentive, decisive, facilitative and extremely communicative. They actioned scans, treatment, medication and care for my mum and they kept us as a family in the loop at all times. We felt we were provided a cohesive, reliable, professional service. We felt part of the solution and mum was treated with dignity and respect. The only thing I would say could be improved is that we had never heard of this service and quite honestly it has been a god send.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: carinatd56
title: Failure as staff disclose highly sensitive information
body:
After years of bottling up things and depression I finally learnt to trust and talk to a Mental Health worker at Silverlea. I believed that everything I said was private and confidential. I was told that it would remain private unless I said something that endangered myself or someone else.  
Then after a stay in ICU, I applied for my medical records to understand why I had ended up in ICU. I discovered that Silverlea had called the Hospital and divulged highly sensitive information from over 50 years ago to a complete stranger, it had been written in non private hospital notes for all and sundry to read.  
I felt ashamed and guilty, dirty and violated. And the response from Silverlea Mental Health was just the normal typical corporate crappy response:  
We accept more information was passed than should have happened. . We are sorry for this and lessons will be learnt.  
Since this, I have not been able to access any Mental Health input. I have lost all trust in the Medical profession. I have no GP, I have refused ever to visit the hospital again that dealt with my ICU and notes. I think Silverlea Mental Health breached my privacy in a vile way without any consideration for my feelings and it was like idol gossip for them...  
I would never ever trust this service with sensitive information as they do not care about that information or you as a person.  
The information shared was not only defamatory but derogative and I felt made out that I was to blame for what happened to me at 5 years of age?

author: J2887
title: It's like I have to be cured before I get any help
body: I sought help for depression, anxiety and suicidal thoughts. I have had a horrible experience. They have treated me poorly, I feel more depressed and have severe anxiety and anger because of it. They have diagnosed me with a personality disorder but never explained what that is or offered me any help for that. They said the medication I was already on prior to the diagnosis was the treatment for it. Methadone is not prescribed for personality disorders, nor are anti depressants, those were for depression and opiate use. Ever since I told them of my drug use I feel that they were discriminatory against me, and said addiction services will help but they have only put me on methadone and nothing else other than religious programs. I was never addicted to drugs, I used drugs once in a while to help my symptoms of anxiety but never addicted. Now I am addicted to methadone and am being refused mental health treatment until I get off of it. I was drug-free when I first went to them and they put me on drugs. It makes no sense. I was told I would be seeing a psychologist last year but as is usual with so much I have been told it hasn't happened and now they say I am not open to them. I was told I would be seeing Psychologist and it would be soon, that the staff member I spoke to was personally putting it through. Now I'm being told it's addiction services that would be helping me with that but only after I get off methadone. It's like I now have to be cured before I get any help. I was also assured anti-depressants would help, they did not and when I brought this up they denied ever having said that. I am still depressed, suicidal and angry. Some staff also seem to have anger issues and have not acted professionally, or treated me fairly. They say I am a manipulator but I'm only trying to get help, they are scaring me away with how they are treating me. I have had proper treatment in the past so I know how it should go.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: lovely food
body:
Tomorrow will actually be my 2nd week in hospital now.  
All the staff are incredible, the nurses are lovely and always very friendly.  
The cleanliness is great, the ward is very, very clean.  
The food is lovely, I especially love a wee cup of tea and some toast at supper time.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Food is nice, ward is clean
body: I came to lurgan hospital a few weeks ago, I was brought over by my son. The food is really nice, I can’t complain at all. The nurses are absolutely lovely. Cleanliness is amazing, cleaners work so hard to make sure the place is always shining.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff are so patient and caring
body: The staff are so patient and very caring, I can’t thank them enough for all that they do. The food hasn’t been very good, although I understand it is not going to be amazing. I haven’t really enjoyed the food. The cleaners are absolutely great they work very well.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scorpiusjj76
title: Readmitted following an operation
body:
I was admitted to ARI from the GP following an operation the previous day. I was in agony to the point I could not walk unassisted. I was admitted in the afternoon only to be met with rude staff members who did not seem to care. Doctors informed the nurses of my pain management medication for the SCN to tell me that’s extreme for the pain you are experiencing, I could not walk unassisted and could only lie flat on my back, I think this is an unprofessional and not patient centred. The staff contradicted themselves, one minute my bloods were unremarkable and the next I had signs of infection yet did not give me any antibiotics for this, I believe I should have been started on antibiotics, considering I had a high temp and heartrate.  
A hcsw came into the room at one point never said hello and then proceeded to abruptly place a menu for the following day on my table and say I doubt you will be needing that and then they opened the window without asking me beforehand.  
Another hcsw later came into the room and stated because I'm in my early 20's I shouldn't be getting a CT scan.  
Furthermore I was discharged the following day with more painkillers, which did not help and I asked for stronger ones but was told no. I had to contact the gp again for more painkillers.  
I understand and completely empathise with undergoing pressures the nhs deal with daily however no one should face discrimination for their age.

author: Fred1970
title: Lincoln County Hospital
body:
I received a letter with date and time of my surgery at Branston ward, Lincoln County Hospital. My letter stated to be at the ward at a time in the morning, however when I arrived to check in, the nurse checked the board and I was down for a PM surgery. I was told I could drink water up to 11.00 (I had stopped in the early morning, as per my letter) but it was now too late for me to have anything to eat. I was taken down for surgery in the afternoon. After changing into the gown, I went into the theatre, where 2 of the anaesthetist nurses attempted to put the canula in my left hand. After a good 5 minutes and a considerable amount of pain from prodding around, they gave up and had to use my right hand. I was left with a huge, swollen bruise and soreness in my left hand, which is still there almost 2 weeks later. I was taken back to the ward about 2.5 hours later, transferred into bed and then didn't see anyone until I got up to go to the nurses station (another 2 hours after this), to see if I could have a cup of tea and something to eat (it had been 26hrs since I last ate). The nurse said someone should have been to offer me something to eat once back on the ward (no one did). I also had to ask to have the canula removed so I could go home, and again the nurse said that I have to be back from surgery for 2hrs and have eaten before I could leave, which I had, but no one seemed to know this.  
I am very disappointed at the organisation and care given. Going into hospital for surgery is stressful enough, particularly at the moment when we can't have someone with us. The fact that I had to spend all day on the ward, unnecessarily because the time of my surgery was wrong, to then not be checked on afterwards, makes the whole ordeal quite upsetting.

title: Efficient friendly practice
body: As always, a very useful and helpful telephone consultation with the GP updating my current ongoing health issues

title: What a visit to your doctor should be...
body: Walked in without an appointment. Spoke to the receptionist who was efficient but friendly. Ascertained that I was able to see a doctor and was asked to wait a short time. Within minutes I was with the doctor. The doctor asked numerous questions and performed the approximate checks. I felt safe and listened to. Excellent manner. I walked in feeling anxious about my health and left feeling calmer. Well done JS medical and your wonderful staff.

title: Seemless & straight forward
body:
Rang 8am on a Monday, 7th in the queue, waited just over 5 mins and got a same day face to face GP appointment. Self check in on arrival and very thorough service from the GP.
Excellent service all round.

title: Quick to offer help
body: I really appreciate how quickly they give you an appointment if you need one - I never have to worry about not being seen for 3 weeks+ for an issue that needs handling there and then. Wish the whole health service was like this!

title: well organised
body: I was seen very quickly. I was given plenty of information about the  minor surgery and there was no pain or discomfort.

author: Kandygrl22
title: Looked after on labour ward
body:
From the moment we came in to labour ward we were looked after. The midwife immediately took us in to a room and started to do observations on me, all whilst explaining what each aspect meant.  
The same midwife stayed with us from 12am to 8am, bar a 1 hour break.  
We cannot fault the entire team, even when our little girl's heart rate was dropping at the end of labour the team made sure we knew what was going on and safely got her in to the world.  
Tamsin, our main midwife, was incredible. We would just like to say a huge thank you for the effort and support she put in.

title: Caring
body: Had to say that the anaesthetic consultant and her team were the most caring and professional individuals it has been my good fortune to have had looking after me, thankyou so much for all your care and attention. Best doctors ever!!

author: SilverFox73
title: The staff involved could not have done better
body:
I'm not a beach bum or habitual sunbather, perhaps taking my shirt off a few times a year when working outside. Fortunately a friend, a retired dermatologist, suggested I get some marks on my neck looked at. My GP thought they were nothing so my friend gave me the exact words to describe what I needed - that two BCC's require excision. On giving these words to another GP I was invited to the surgery where a referral was made.  
Once in the system things moved relatively quickly considering the Covid impact. I've just had two BCC's removed on my neck and need three to be removed from my back.  
Using local anesthetic the procedure was painless and all involved welcomed me and made me feel comfortable explaining what would be done etc. They even had the decency to laugh at my pathetic jokes they've probably heard countless times. They also respected my hearing loss ensuring I understood what was going on and after care etc.  
All in all the staff involved could not have done better with what they have to work with. What a shame the system is so cumbersome and top heavy giving the NHS such a bad reputation.

title: Caring and compassionate
body:
I am a recovering alcoholic and I have called an ambulance,  wanted to stop drinking but was very anxious about detox. I've been taken to Basildon Hospital. The care I have received was extraordinary. Staff was caring,  compassionate, patient, helpful,  gave me hope for the better future every moment I've approached them. They were like a guardian angers in one of the hardest moments of my life. 
Keeping things short... a year in line, I'm still sober, praying for them. 
Thank you.

title: Fantastic Staff
body: I am always really impressed by this practice. The doctors are efficient, caring and clinically excellent. They clearly work very hard and it is much appreciated. The reception staff are helpful and I have nothing but praise for them.

title: Amazing doctor in A&E
body: Just wanted to thank the amazing doctor we had in A&E last night. I can’t remember his name but it was from Iran and training as a GP here in the UK.  My fathers had severe dementia and Alzheimer’s and had taken a fall with an irregular heartbeat. He was so kind and patient, and so wonderful with my dad. The nurses were also were patient with him. A wonderful service, thank you

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Pauleenspens
title: Putting patients at ease is paramount to the job
body: I was admitted to RAH paisley on Friday night with a dislocated hip. I was in much distress and pain and the staff were fantastic,however one of the porters I feel could and should have been more caring and less short in tone with patients. I am 47 years old and 3years into a hip replacement I was very upset at the trauma I was experiencing and kind words and disposition would have been much appreciated and noted. Instead I was met with a lack of compassion and made to feel more scared than I already was. Dealing with distressed patients I feel putting them at ease is paramount to the job.

title: Great service
body: Got appointment for blood test very friendly staff , very good service, clean practice, the lady was serving me very good and covid safe

title: The Best
body: Everyone always so helpful and kind I could not ask for more, I also now use ask my GP online and i really like it. a big thank you to you all

title: Fantastic staff
body: I was seen at the Basford clinic and the staff and nurses were fantastic. I was treated with respect, the procedure was explained to me and they were patient and sympathetic.  Thanks to all at the clinic x

title: Pleasantly suprised
body: I used the online request for a GP to discuss my symptoms and I asked for a phone call or text reply, I did not think an appointment was needed for my problem. I knew the phone lines are often busy, so this was a great option for me. I was expecting a reply in a couple of days but was pleasantly surprised to get a call back the same morning from a GP and my problem quickly and efficiently sorted. Good service!

title: Very helpful experience at a difficult time
body: Feeling that something was 'not quite right' with my husband (72) for some time, but unsure what, I booked an appointment for him to see the Practice Nurse.  She listened carefully to both my and my husband's concerns and then quickly referred us to one of the GPs. During the telephone consultation the following week, the GP again listened carefully to our concerns, then booked a face-to-face appointment with her. Things then happened quickly, and we were referred to Kings College Hospital Neurology Department.  Following tests and scans, my husband's diagnosis was confirmed, and treatment started.  He is responding well and I know without a doubt that the quick response from the Surgery Nurse and GP, things could have been much worse for my husband.  We both cannot thank them enough for their kindness and their professional help. We have full confidence and trust in them.

title: Lucky to be registered with Lea Surgery
body:
It is with great pleasure I am giving this feedback. 
I am very happy with the care I receive at Lea Surgery.
My GP is very knowledgeable, listens patiently, provides sounds advice, and involves me in decisions about my treatment.  I have been able to see the see the same GP most of the time. This has provided continuity of care. At times, I have consulted other doctors.
Over the years, I have seen lot of positive changes in the Surgery and these changes have made this Surgery, one amongst the best.
I have heard from friends about the difficulties they faced regarding their GP surgery: e.g unable to get an appointment for several days/weeks; must call in the morning for appointment, but phone rings and rings but not picked up; must wait for up to 2 weeks to see a GP; seeing different GP’s each time.
My experience at Lea Surgery has been different. Generally, I have not had difficulty to get through to the ‘Reception’ by phone, nor to arrange an appointment with the doctor. The reception staff have always been cordial and helpful. Appointments have been available on the same day or the next day. This Surgery is open 7 days a week, which is a boon. Results etc can be checked through online service provided. 
The Pharmacist has been helpful in answering questions on medication and explains about possible side effects of new medication. The Nurse Practitioners are knowledgeable and provide good advice in their field of expertise. Asthma checks, Diabetes checks and advice on management are given as needed
The health care assistants do a great job and makes life easier as samples (bloods and urine) are taken at the surgery, thereby avoiding having to go to the hospital for the same
The Plus Points about Lea Surgery:
Clean premises and committed staff
Knowledgeable and caring professional staff; Treated me with dignity, and respect
Hardly any difficulty in getting appointments
Open 7 days a week
Able to see the same doctor, if needed. Enables continuity of care
Availability of online services
I have witnessed lot of improvements over the years. The document in the waiting area ‘you said it we did It’, mentions about changes which patients wanted and which were implemented in the Surgery
I consider myself lucky in being with Lea Surgery and do not have any hesitation in recommending people who have had problems with their GP surgeries, to the Lea Surgery

title: Very inconvenient
body: To book an appointment, you have to call at 8am. They have never mentioned this to any existing patients so i spent over 10 minutes on hold to just be told in under 30 seconds that i have to wait until tomorrow 8 am to book. Quite frustrating if i do say so myself.

author: La26
title: My 10month old daughters ECO scan
body:
We arrived and followed the instructions given via text message to click on the link to say we’ve arrived and wait for a message to say they’re ready for us to come in. We waited 45minutes in our car, before receiving the message to be told when we arrived that we were late, so they had allowed other patients in before us. My daughter had her height and weight done and some other checks on her chest. We then had to wait in a corridor on a chair for 1hour 30minutes. No area for my daughter to be able to be put down, so I was desperately trying to keep her occupied on my lap (which is not easy with a newly active baby). When we got called in for her ECO scan, it was by far the worst experience I have had at the hospital (we spent a lot of time in and out of hospital with my first child). My daughter hates getting dressed and undressed and is not afraid to tell you (very loud screaming crying). Let alone this being the 3rd member of staff we’ve seen since arriving. As expected from a 10month old (I work in a nursery so she is definitely not the only one to get unsettled by strangers), my daughter screamed and cried as loud as she could as soon as the doctor looked at her, let alone trying to touch her chest. To my shock, the doctor asked me if she is always this naughty. I responded saying she’s not naughty, she doesn’t like strangers approaching her.  
The doctor then repeatedly questioned why I couldn’t settle her. I was left in the room with the doctor while I tried to get her to fall asleep (she was knackered). I told the doctor she would still wake up when they touched her as she’s a light sleeper.  
They made it clear that they were getting annoyed and made me feel like it was my fault that she was so upset. They said to come back in 4/6 months and they would have to sedate her.  
They then went on to say the complete opposite of every other doctor we had seen up until recently. I left that room crying. I’ve never been made to feel like that by a professional. I will not be returning to this doctor.

title: Absolutely shocking
body: I have been with this surgery for 33 years and when I started me and my family had the same doctor who was amazing,in the last 5 years it has gone massively downhill and I have waited for near on 3 weeks just for a telephone appointment,they need a major shake up in how they speak to patients and how the practice is run because it’s exactly what it says it’s more like practising than practice.

title: Ask to many unhelpful things
body: When you phone up you are asked way too many questions before you can be told about getting a call back if you then even get the call back. You are now asked what the reason for the callback is. So upon ringing a mental health crisis line they actually want to know what you want to discuss even though it's a nurse you want to speak with. If this is now going to make it even harder to get a call back then what really is the point in contacting here to start with. They really do say such stupid things to you and by asking even more details then you are waiting even longer than ever for a call back. Upon sometimes getting a call back they then hang up on you just as you pick up the phone it's not at all helpful. They are saying at other times that you haven't even answered the call when they haven't called you back it's very annoying and they get so much incorrect but still blame you no matter what. They need to step up to the plate and do the job they are paid to do

readBy.name: Cumbria, Northumberland, Tyne and Wear NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent treatment
body: As an out-patient, all staff were courteous and friendly and I had my diagnostic treatment explained before and during the process.  I cannot stress highly enough the standard of excellence at this hospital during these present ongoing difficult times.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: The best maternity experience I could have asked…
body: I can’t thank all of the staff in the maternity Ward enough for their kindness are care during my difficult labour at Good Hope! The level of care and expertise received was exceptional and I couldn’t have asked for anything more! Every single member of staff we came across were simply amazing! So knowledgeable, kind, compassionate and went above and beyond at every moment! Despite a very traumatic labour ending in theatre I never once felt scared or worried as I could see even in the midst of the drama that I was in the best hands! The calmness and control they all displayed during surgery kept me and my husband calm and reassured throughout! The way the midwives, consultants, anaesthesia dr and many other staff cared for me during this time was so reassuring. I literally cannot thank all of the staff enough for all they have done for me and my baby son whilst in their care! You are all such wonderful people and we won’t forget all that you did!

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: excellent staff and service
body: From reception onwards staff wrere extremely curteous and professional. Waiting times were minimal considering the footfall of patients at the time of my visit. I left feeling that my case had been fully investigated and appropriate medication prescribed

title: Appalling Service and Rude
body: A service in decline, after a call to 111 I was asked to attend the hospital at a certain time, 6 hours later and I’m still waiting to be seen, rude staff and no information available, quite appalling and unnecessary.

readBy.name: The Queen Elizabeth Hospital Kings Lynn NHS Foundation Trust

author: Relative79
title: Easy to use service
body:
Rang and booked - it was really easy and even when I didn't get an answer on one occasion I was called back very quickly.
The team were absolutely brilliant not just during the booking but also at the time of the visit when they set up the call and made sure that everything was working well
Dad is only allowed one visitor once a week so this is a really valuable service for patients in his situation.
Great job team - keep up the great work!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Katee95
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Two weeks in orthopaedics
body: I arrived into hospital about 4 weeks ago and was then transferred into the orthopaedic ward after 2 weeks. I have had serious problems with my hip and was getting checked for arthritis and osteoporosis. My hip mobility has been deteriorating in recent times and I knew if it was sorted I would end up in  a wheelchair. The pain I was going through was immense so to be getting sorted was fantastic. I underwent surgery a week ago and received a full hip replacement. I already notice the difference in my hip which I am so grateful for. When I arrive home, there will be care coming into help me with my recovery as I live alone. I couldn't fault the orthopaedic ward and want to thank everyone in it!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: An 8 day wait for an "on the day"telephone…
body: I phoned the surgery at 8 am. The taped message told me to hold the line for an "on the day" telephone consultation.  After 45 minutes I spoke to a receptionist who wanted to know all my symptoms and who suggested that I go to A&E - for inexplicable exhaustion. She then offered me a phone consultation 8 (eight) days later. The taped message mentioned the practice website which has been out of action for quite a few days now.

author: Markle
title: Great hospital care
body:
Last week I had a minor heart attack at home. My wife dialled 999 and after a wait of only half an hour an ambulance appeared.( The ambulance came from Edinburgh and we live just outside East Linton, so well done)  
I was taken to Royal Infirmary with the paramedics stabilising my condition.  
Hardly no wait at Royal where I was seen by A& E doctor and it was after blood tests that confirmed I had a heart attack. Ten minutes later I was informed I was having another one. The A & E was very busy but through the chaos calm was restored.  
I was moved to an acute ward who looked after myself for 1 night before a bed was found on the cardiac ward 103. Here for two nights, well done to everybody who works here under immense pressure to deliver caring standard’s. On Monday I had an angiogram everybody here was great and explained everything to the nth degree. Home Monday night feet up for 10 days and told to be careful. Follow up has been great too.  
Well done NHS

title: Unable to book a telephone appointment
body: I have been trying constantly for the past couple of days to book a telephone appointment. I have phoned at exactly 8am each morning but have not been able to get through as all the lines are busy how is that possible. Finally managed to get through at 9am only to be told that I need to phone at 8am and that all the slots have gone and to call back tm. This is unacceptable what does one have to do to get through

author: agm2022
title: Great care and attention
body: Care and attention was great at the New Victoria Doctor was lovely 🥰 girl two nurses were great very attentive I felt like a VIP no complaints at all. Taken at correct time of appointment.

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: It’s been a ten out of ten experience.
body:
My care in the hospital has been first class and that is due to the sheer quality of nurses we have here in the hospital.  
The doctors come in and are quick and do what needs to be done whereas the nursing staff put so much time and effort into us as patients and people which is something I am so grateful for.  
I couldn’t complain about any of the staff I see on the ward all of them domestic’s cleaners etc. are all just exceptional and are underappreciated as to the work they do.  
From getting to A and E a week and a half ago until now it’s been a ten out of ten experience.  
The food is also brilliant, you always get enough and if you don’t like something the staff always find a replacement or something to change this.  
There are times on the ward at which I have been unable to sleep due to the noise levels of other patients and machine however I understand that there is other people struggling in the hospital so I am not that worried about this.  
I am very grateful for all the staff and hope to be discharged next week

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The hospital has been excellent
body:
My care has been very good so far in the hospital.  
The nursing staff are exceptional and treat me incredibly kind and with an incredible level of respect.  
The doctors are brilliant and explained everything about my treatment in the simplest manner making it easy to understand.  
The food has been lovely ever since I arrived in the building. I always get more than enough to satisfy my appetite.  
Everything has also been so clean since I arrived from the bathrooms to my table is outstanding.  
The hospital has been excellent and I am grateful for my treatment

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Dilegience of the staff have made care amazing
body:
My care has been very good ever since arriving at the ward because of the diligence of the staff in making sure I am treated amazingly. Any reasonable request is done with such urgency and perfection it’s truly an art.  
The staff are always there to listen at your bedside and their knowledge truly shines through in the recovery period as they know what works and what doesn’t which has made my time in hospital a lot easier.  
The food has been so nice so far and I always get enough which is excellent as it helps me with my energy level.  
The doctors are also lovely and always make things easy to understand.  
I have no issues and couldn’t say a bad word about any part of the hospital

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Patient1982!
title: I had ruptured my Achilles’ tendon
body:
I was refereeing a football match and was 40 mins into the first half and was back pedalling and felt like I had gone down a pothole or been kicked in the back of the leg. I tried to stand up and couldn’t place weight on my left leg.  
The physio came on and from his experience he thought immediately I had ruptured my Achilles tendon.  
I was then taken to nearby Crosshouse Hospital and examined. It was confirmed I had ruptured my Achilles’ tendon. I was deflated as I knew how long a recovery this was - and I was a very active person so knowing I won’t be able to walk or run for some time was like a kick in the gut!  
I then was told to come back a few days later and was thankfully seen by a specialist who advised Percutaneous Achilles Repair System (PARS) surgery two days later.  
I was then operated on and in a cast for two weeks then into a walking boot for 5 weeks. Then full weight bearing.

author: CatLady31322
title: I could not have had a better experience
body:
I attended Maternity Triage at Ninewells on Monday for an induction via balloon. I was welcomed by a midwife who made my husband and I feel instantly at ease through fully explaining every step of the process and answering any questions I had with evidence based knowledge. The midwife and her healthcare assistant were an asset (it can be quite daunting showing your all when it's your first baby).  
On Tuesday the balloon was taken out and I was sent home to await a bed in the Labour suite to break my waters.  
My waters broke and contractions started early on Wednesday morning and triage via phone were very helpful in explaining why I'd be best to begin early labour at home until they got stronger.  
By lunchtime this became more unmanageable and I was given the choice to be reviewed by triage if I wished despite early labour which I took!  
Once accessed I was indeed in labour and taken to the Labour suite for pain management.  
Catriona who was assisting from DMU took over my care with support from Pia (student midwife). Catriona made me feel very reassured and supported me to follow my birth plan wish of a natural labour as much as possible, waiting for me to call the shots in terms of pain relief instead of pushing it on me. Pia ensured that my family were cared for and nothing was of too much hassle.  
Layla took over my care onto the Nightshift and in all honestly; I would like to place this woman on a pedestal for all the world to see as she is truly such an asset to the NHS.  
From the moment I met Layla I knew she had complete control. Straight away she could see I was uncomfortable (half way down the bed) and instead of waiting until I was ready to move (which would have been never), adjusted my position according to my pain and took some easy decisions away from me so I could focus on me.  
In the evening, Layla held me up when I was close to passing out getting my epidural, never agreed with me (when I said I must've been hurting her grabbing her arm or leaning on her) and most importantly; listened to my every need.  
Following my epidural she ensured I was fed, hydrated and rested. In between began IV drips and communicated with doctors and anesthetics about my poor vein quality and babies occasional drop in heart rate, which the consultant Rosie assessed each time. After 6 hours of more contractions and ever growing pain, Layla encouraged me to put everything into my pushing and made me feel a bit like superwoman when I pushed in the right place.  
Very early the next morning, I was aware that the room was becoming more full with medical staff and Rosie (consultant) explained that baby was occasionally in distress and we needed to work very hard on my pushes.  
I was consented for forceps shortly following this (just in case it were required) and thank goodness this was done without any wait as babies heart rate suddenly shot up and I was rushed to theatre very quickly to go on to have my baby less than an hour later.  
In theatre, staff explained everything well (I was so worried he hasn't cried) and let my husband be a vital part in my babies beginning of life whilst I was being cared for. Staff appeared to genuinely congratulate my husband and I and, I felt like we had all completed a marathon together with the celebrations!  
Rosie and a member of the anaesthetic team were so kind to visit me on the ward that evening/the next day to explain everything and I know now that if my baby had not been delivered then and there, things could have taken a turn for the worse and due to Rosie, Layla and the senior charge nurses quick decision making; I have the most perfect healthy baby.  
After baby was born, Layla and student midwife Tia ensured I was comfortable and so compassionate when I explained the first present I opened was a knitted item from my recently deceased mother that my neighbour finished knitting.  
On ward 38 South I would like to thank all the midwives that took care of us, especially with their breastfeeding support as I know if I hadn't been an inpatient, I would have given up!  
I'd like to give a special nod to the student midwife Cameron on 38 who, in a world of judgement, carried out a majority female profession with such confidence, especially in his great communication and breastfeeding support.  
As you can see by my essay that I write at a very early morning feed (hehe), I have taken the time to to give proper feedback to maternity services at Ninewells as truly I could not have had a better experience (despite the issues we had) and the staff should be truly praised for the work they do; so much more than my bag of tea and coffee could ever do.

author: GillyMeg
title: Nhs Lanarkshire
body: My almost 91 year old mum admitted from her home to University Hospital Hairmyres. After a few hours in a hectic A&E she was transferred to ward 4 overnight and then to ward 15 for care. She was there 16 days and tested positive for covid the night before transfer to a care home, as we sadly couldn’t give give the care required at home any longer. She was transferred to ward 3 for a couple of days then onto ward 6 covid ward. Once out, her isolation in the care home was closed due to Covid issues, so she was transferred to Stonehouse Hospital for 18 days before eventually transferring to the care home. The care and support given to mum was fabulous and under Johns Campaign, I was able to visit and feed mum. The wards are struggling with high volume of patients and staff off sick yet they all took time to speak with me and ensure mum had what she required. I am proud to be a mum of an NHS nurse and see first hand what her and her colleagues do on a daily basis. They work so hard and do their very best to ensure patients and families are supported.

author: Days
title: Outstanding care
body:
It wouldn’t be possible to personally thank everyone who was involved in our teenage daughter’s recent care. It was impeccable at every stage and hopefully this goes some small way to recognising it.  
Our daughter developed what we assumed was a tummy bug late on Thursday night, after a day off school and plenty of bed rest, by Saturday morning it was becoming a bit more concerning.  
NHS24 arranged a doctor call back which came quickly and we were referred to the out of hours GP at Hamilton, eventually being sent to Monklands where she was diagnosed with appendicitis and operated on first thing on Sunday morning. All in, from that first call to operation was less than 24 hours.  
Through this, we were met by professionalism and compassion, every person we dealt with on the journey went above and beyond to help us all, but especially our daughter. I felt relaxed and informed, and an anxious time for us was made as easy as possible.We can’t thank enough all the staff, nurses, doctors and surgeons at NHS24, Hamilton Medical Centre, and Monklands Hospital.  
Our daughter is now back home, out of pain, and mostly recovered with little to show for her experience other than a couple of minor scars.  
Thank you all so much, our eternal gratitude.

author: lmmecs45804
title: Emergency Surgery
body:
My relative found the staff were very unprofessional in Ward 6A RVH. A complaint has been submitted and many apologies made.  
Staff made the patient’s stay difficult and were uncaring, rude, unprofessional and neglectful.  
The patient had many positive experiences in every other hospital and ward they had been in (over 26 years). Hospital had become a second home, attending hospitals weekly. Most staff were helpful and caring. This was not the case in Ward 6A RVH.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Katee95
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Orthopaedic care
body:
After falling awkwardly, I broke a bone in my foot so had to come into the orthopaedic ward as I require an operation.  
The doctor's have decided to wait until the swelling in my foot is entirely down and then they can proceed with the surgery.  
The staff in here have been lovely and so approachable. The hygiene is super and the cleaners are always busy.  
The food is surprisingly delightful- hospital food is synonymous with being ''inedible'' but I don't have a bad word to say about the food in orthopaedics.  
I am happy with how everything is going, it's just a case of taking it day by day and hoping the swelling goes down.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Patcash
title: Made me feel that someone cared all the way through
body:
I found a lump in my breast on Wednesday night, by Friday had seen my own gp.  
By following Wednesday had mammograms, scans, biopsies and had been diagnosed with breast cancer.  
Went following week for vacuum biopsy in Glasgow.  
10 days later had my breast removed at Royal Alexandra Hospital. The care given at Royal Alexandra Hospital was wonderful. The consultants, nurses etc made me feel that someone cared all the way through.

author: JohnJ2022
title: Attending PrEP clinic
body: I booked in to get a kidney function and sex health screening for a PrEP prescription. very friendly nurse led service, in and out within 15 mins.

title: A General Review
body:
Mocketts Wood continues to be one of the better medical practices in Thanet, with good nursing and doctors 

However they have yet to resume their previous walk in surgery on Monday and Friday between 9am and 1pm. 

Given a degree of cooperation with staff and patients regarding masks and Covid this could work very well indeed in reducing appointment work load

In addition the Surgery has a big garden where a tent could be pitched (Mocketts Wood have done this before) to reduce further any infection risk

I look forward to seeing a resumption of this service

author: stonem
title: I have wet and macular degeneration
body: After being diagnosed with wet macular in my eye, I have to attend the eye clinic at Treliske hospital. I get the train to Truro then walk over the railway bridge using the scenic walk to Treliske. I get the train in the morning (which confuses my Doggy as he thinks that he is getting an early morning walkies). Once at the hospital, I check in and wait to be called. I always wear a mask in case someone might recognize me and because of the virus. When my name is called, I go to the pre lab to see how my eyesight is doing. I think I am on my fourth jab. Both my eyes are tested with a one eyed jack to see if my vision is improving in my left eye. It is. Once I am through, I am shown to a comfy chair in front of the operating room. I manage to read half a page of my current book before being called in. I lie down on a bunk bed and am given drops to anaesthetize my eye. Next is the injection and I have to be very still. Difficult. All of this is done with great care and attention from the nurses. I am most grateful that this treatment is available to me and delivered with such gentle kindness. I don't think I would be able to pay for this wonderful treatment if our health service was privatised. I don't know the names of the lovely staff who have been so kind, but on my next visit I shall endeavour to find out their names.

title: no one answers the phone
body: Been trying to get hold of the GP line is always busy and there is no voicemail or email service to ask anyone to call back

title: Excellent nurse care
body:
Had an operation on 18/02/22 that needed packing and dressing every day, to date. I have been to numerous surgeries and have been very well looked after by all the nurses that I have met.
I cannot speak highly enough of their professionalism as well as having a chat whilst being treated.
All the nurses are a credit to the NHS.

title: Appointment with doctors never available
body:
Appointment never available, calling from 8am trying to book the appointment, hanging on the phone for 1 h and 40 min just to hear that the appointment for today aren't available, please call tomorrow. You are calling tomorrow and us the same story, please call tomorrow. 

Disgusting

author: trig72
title: Daily care
body: My sister , who has MS, is admitted to hospital every 3 months and every time without exception, she is treated with the utmost respect, patience and care... This is also mirrored in any situation regarding the above persons... I cannot stress enough how much this means to all our family. I, and the family, would like to thank each and every single person who tends to my sister... Your much appreciated and should be told that daily... God bless and stay safe 💜💜x

title: Extremely poor
body: Took 4 days with constant calls to get through . Finally my last attempt before I actually was going to go there someone answered then put me on hold then put the phone down ! I’m calling for medical reasons they couldn’t care less

author: orionjt83
title: Hearing impaired in emergency dept
body: I experienced poor practice for patients with hearing impairment while waiting in ED. Despite informing reception, my name was called over tannoy, which I cannot hear (luckily a relative insisted on staying for this reason). Despite then reiterating this to a nurse, I was called again via tannoy. My relative was unable to leave to go to toilet etc in the meantime in case I missed being called. A buzzer system would be a suggestion - one that activates a vibration when it is your turn (or a screen with name and where to go to although this would not suit those with visual impairment). Simple changes would make an already stressful situation more bearable.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: lyrazn78
title: Dermatology nurse clinic appointment
body: Attended Crosshouse Hospital Ward 2e nurses clinic and was seen by Nurse Innes and her colleague. Both nurses were very professional and gave excellent care throughout. Explained what they were doing and reassured me at all times. Aftercare and follow up arrangements were explained. Made the experience less stressful. Well done ladies!

title: Awful service!  Waste of time
body:
Absolutely livid!!!
Had a nurse appt, who then advised I need to see a dr.  Then had to wait over two weeks for an appt.  
Tried asking for one sooner but no luck.

Had my appt today, arranged childcare as it’s school half term.  Sat in reception for 20 mins before being told my appt was meant to be a phone call and receptionist apologised as admitted I was never told as it was a blip with their system.  (Not sure why, it would be a phone appt when I was told I would need to see a dr for my symptoms.)

Anyway… after another 5 minutes I get sent away saying the dr will call me later in the week and I wouldn’t have an appt at all today!!!!

Now apparently I’ve just got to wait for another telephone appt when they will probably tell me I need to come in to be assessed! 

Nightmare unorganised surgery!

I feel sorry for the reception staff, who are nice, but unfortunately get the brunt of annoyed patients. The receptionist have a very tough job as have to deliver all the bad news.

title: An outstanding practice: a shining beacon of the…
body:
My recent telephone appointment with my GP exceeded all of my expectations which has consistently been the case ever since I joined this practice in 2015.
I am extremely fortunate to have a GP who is both incredibly professional and empathetic towards my chronic health conditions. He treated me (as he always does) with respect and listened very carefully to my current concerns and adjusted my medication accordingly which, after allowing just over a week for the revised dosage to take effect, has made a real improvement to the quality of my life for which I am truly grateful. 
I cannot praise my GP highly enough since he deserves every bit of praise and recognition for all that he does (and has done over the years) for me which I am sure is true for all of his patients. To me he represents the very best of the best and is embodiment of excellence.
Thank you so very much.

title: Good practice
body: Why do I have to make an appointment at 6oclock in the morning on the Internet, I use to go on appointments and  choose a time and doctor to see ,2 or 3 day's  ahead, during a working day .at 6oclock I am at work.

title: Online system shortfall
body: The service is not up to standard needed. I used to receive prescription repeats through Tesco Pharmacy for the daily medication I require online on the NHS service. That ability has been taken away, so now I need to call the surgery, which it is virtually impossible to get through to. As a result, I only have three days medication left. Further training or staffing is surely needed.

title: impossible to get through. If you do they don’t…
body: Called 24 times on one occasion before someone answered . Asked to speak to duty team 7 different times . No one called back . Allocated a “support worker” never answers messages and impossible to get hold of . No support whatsoever especially when in crisis .

title: Really quick response, great service
body: I contacted the surgery on Monday morning and used the online form which stated I would get a response in 2 days. Within 10 minutes I was called by a GP who completed an assessment and issued a prescription direct to my pharmacy which was ready to collect within a couple of hours. Much better than waiting on hold on the phone, trying to get booked in and travelling to the surgery for an appointment/ to collect the prescription then schlep to the pharmacy. I know the surgery gets a lot of flack, especially these days, but I was really impressed by the service and it was good to have my mind put at rest about my condition by a friendly and professional GP.

title: Your response to my review
body: Thank you for your response to my experience. I believe it would be better to put callers into a queue at 0800 or later, when they call. When I called this week I had to listen to your recorded message over 15 times before I was able to make contact. This seems unecessary to me. I have used econsult and found it a good service but my second visit to econsult suggested I make an appointment with a doctor. When I eventually made contact the appointment and subsequent action was efficient.

author: EmmaW28
title: Things moved fast
body: I gave birth to my second child back in November and I have to say the care within ward 7 at FVRH was second to none. With it being a second pregnancy I was advised by the community midwives that things can move much quicker and they weren’t wrong! Haha! From my first call into triage to delivery and post natal care I can’t thank and praise the midwives enough. Karen in triage, and Lorraine who delivered my little girl. Thank you so much! You were both so caring, supportive and made it all such a lovely experience!

title: Awful service don’t register here
body:
Huge phone waiting times, impossible to get to see a doctor without a battle, my referral was not actioned for a month then I had to call to check on it, still can’t be actioned because yet another doctor has left and the rest seem incapable of reading a clinical history. Reception and impersonal and uncaring and never apologise.
If you can’t call at 8am for a phone appt. (Even this not possible on some days for some doctors) good luck ever getting seen or heard. Absolutely appalling. Wish I had never registered.

title: Excellent attention and care
body: I booked on line for my worries, promptly booked and called,disscussed nearly 30 minutes and clarified everything...now my blood pressure normal,relaxed,very happy...excellent service

title: Poor organisation and performance
body:
My orthopaedic appointment letter told me to report to outpatients. When I did, I was told this was wrong and I had to go to a separate building where orthopaedics were based. No easy task as I am wheelchair based. 

When I checked in at orthopaedic reception they kept asking me why I was attending as they had either no record or an inadequate record. I was then sent through to a waiting area where I was presented with a long questionnaire about my shoulder pain. I was, in fact, attending for an examination of a swollen elbow. I was seen by a doctor who said that there was no need for treatment so all in all, this was a complete waste of half a day, when I should have been at work.

author: Connor89
title: Getting an implant removed
body: She was amazing very welcoming and very gentle when taking my implant out didn't feel a thing she was lovely

title: Waste of time
body: Needed a fit to work abroad letter. Got an appointment with a nurse who was lovely. When I phoned to get the letter the reception staff were rude telling me they can't give me one and I need an appointment, although I had already had the appointment. Got a phone call from the doctor who said I need to see him directly because I need to have the tests done again and he can't give me one because he didn't see me. Wasted my time and the nhs's time. Always take over an hour to get an appointment and my call normally gets cut off after about half an hour.

title: Can't get through on the phone
body: I have been trying to get through on the telephone for two hours. I waited until after 11.00 and didn't ring on a Monday because they are busy. When can you bother them? Held in a q "we know you are waiting" "call is important to us", cuts off! Three attempts hanging on then cut off, been trying since 11 it is now 1 pm. Appalling I need test results. Last time I walked up there and people were leaving rather than q through door with only one person on reception.

author: Edel
title: Everyone was so helpful
body: I attended an appointment with my mum and everyone was so helpful.from screening to getting her dye test. Thankful for these staff as it can be a worrying time. Nurses are stretched and still keep smiling. Thank you

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Glasgow2022
title: Our Mum
body: Our mum was in ward 18a where she sadly passed away. We found the nursing staff to be very caring, attentive and informative. SCN, Michelle was always on hand for any questions we might have and always answered right away with honesty. We would like to thank the exceptional hostess, Linda, for always providing tea, coffee etc, anything she could, nothing was too much trouble for her, even making us laugh at this sad time. Thank you ward 18a for making an awful time a bit more bearable

title: Very Disappointed - reception - have a little…
body:
My son is 5 years old. He is non verbal and autistic. I took him to this clinic for a blood test today. It was understandably a distressing experience for him, and the staff taking his blood did their best.

What happened afterward with the receptionist was the problem. My son was upset, and after multiple attempts to clean him up and cover his wound, had blood over half of his face. Seeing that all he wanted was to get outside, the clinical assistant led us to the first of three exits we were not allowed to use. 

The third one she left us at was the one we had entered through. I pressed the button to leave, my son crying his eyes out, blood all over his face. The receptionist, who had barely looked up when checking us in, took the trouble to come out of her booth to tell us that we were not allowed to go through that door. 

I explained that we had already been lead to two other exits, neither of which was accessible, and that we had just been lead to this one. She simply repeated that we were not allowed to go through that door. She had allowed a patient through that door when we were in the waiting room earlier. He appeared more obviously disabled than more son. 

The door is made of glass. There was no one on the other side, or outside of the building. No. Instead, for the sake of Covid safety, we had to pass 5 people in the waiting room and go around the building to the fourth exit. This is not Covid safe, despite her blind following of the rules. 

It was obvious my son was upset. Obvious what he needed. It would take nothing to let us through that door. It was far more important to her to exercise the little power she has. 

Please try to read the situation. You could have lessened his suffering with just a little compassion.

readBy.name: Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust

author: reticulumdn94
title: Prescription Issues
body:
I am at home now really poorly and unfit to even get my prescription from the pharmacy.  
I was ill last week which led to me being in hospital, and I couldn't attend an appointment due to this. I rung them and told them and they said they will be in touch but I really need to come in or it may affect your script. I told them I was far too ill to come or I would.  
The next day I went for my script and it wasn't at the pharmacy. I found out when it was too late that they had stopped my script and put me on every day pick up at a chemist 3-4 miles away. I told them I have been ill yet I have to walk all the way there and back to have my prescription. Anyway when I finally had walked there I was told by the pharmacy that my prescription dose has gone from 60ml down to 30ml instantly over night. I cannot believe they can play god with medication that I need and rely on just to function daily.  
So now I'm withdrawing at home because I'm too ill to walk 3-4 mile to the chemist to get my half dose.

title: Great Staff
body: Attended for a colonoscopy. All of the medical staff, without exception, were very friendly and very helpful, which made a stressful situation far more comfortable.

readBy.name: Mid Cheshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Such incredible service/staff
body: Attended A&E re:eye trauma.Was processed through the system extremely quickly.professionalism was shown by ALL staff from receptionist to Consultant and all those staff inbetween/back of house..i could not have asked for better care or attention. Very reassuring & informative care. Thankyoi

title: Fantastic treatment
body:
Although I work at Barlborough in the ophthalmic theatre I was extremely nervous on the day of my surgery and I would like to say from the first step going to the ward to leaving after the surgery I was treated with respect and dignity from all of the staff involved 
I would highly recommend Newmedica for any eye surgery

author: Boona
title: Mixed reception at Xray department
body:
I was referred for an MRI scan at Crosshouse Hosptial. I arrived and checked in. Didn't have to wait too long and a very pleasant nurse (I assume) collected me and took me along to the MRI area. She was very friendly, chatty and helpful.  
She then left me with the people carrying out the scan. The difference couldn't have been more drastic. The two staff members I dealt with were unpleasant, stern and devoid of any emotion and extremely formal. I felt quite uncomfortable and was glad when the whole thing was over and I could leave.

title: Great practice
body: The doctors are brilliant, they keep check ups withyou via  phone calls, spend time listening to you, always there to help you, so glad I moved to this practice

title: Kindness all round
body:
Today I visited The Outpatients dept for an appointment in cardiology.First time there.
I came into contact with switchboard staff, receptionist and medical staff. All were helpful, kind and considerate.
I felt happy with their Covid prevention.

title: Recommend this practice
body: Every time I have needed to speak with a GP or the nurse it has been facilitated quickly.  The receptionists are easy to speak to and in my experience always try to get you the help that you need.  I would be devastated to lose this single GP practice.

author: SCME
title: Maternity Care
body:
My husband and I welcomed our baby boy in March 2022 in CAH. The care we received was second to none and I have felt strongly that I must send a message, commenting on my positive experience as I feel the staff involved really warrant recognition.  
I was scheduled for a caesarean section for the Thursday morning and having gestational diabetes, it meant I had to stay over night beforehand to be monitored. I was taken care of by a lovely midwife called Jenny, who could not have done any more to make sure I was relaxed, before going down for the surgery and made sure I knew what was involved. I was then met by Rachel and Fionnuala down in delivery, who again put me through the process, ensuring I was aware of what would be happening and in what structure. Both girls were so knowledgeable and offered to answer any questions my husband and I had. They put me completely at ease and just added to the whole experience. Dr Lydia, Dr Mairead and Dr Colin were just amazing during the section and talked to me throughout making sure I knew what was going on every step of the way!  
After a successful surgery, we were brought to recovery where my husband and I were brought the most amazing tea and toast. Due to a Cat1 call, midwife Fionnuala had to run so we were put in the care of trainee midwives, Erin and Laura. Again, both girls were just amazing and monitored both my son and I until we were able to go back to the ward. (Fionnuala then came up to the ward at the end of her shift to check on me and baby which I thought was just so lovely!)  
In the ward (2 West) my care really was second to none. I was looked after by midwife Margaret, who was so attentive to both me and my son. Anything I asked of her was no problem. She was so thorough and it was clear she is so passionate about what she does. Health care assistant, Vicky, was also someone who really stood out to me in my short stay in hospital. She went out of her way to make sure I was freshened up after the surgery so I would start to feel myself again and got a fan for the room. It is clear it is a real vocation for Vicky as everything she done was so patient centred.  
The day after the section I had asked Sister France if it was possible for me to go home. After speaking with the midwife looking after me that day, Catriona, she made sure that everything was checked and put into place so I could go home that evening. Both were so efficient and really listened to what I wanted and made sure it was possible given that baby and I were healthy enough.  
Given that my stay in hospital was short, I have to say that my care was nothing short of amazing. The video shared before we left made my husband and I both feel more at ease as we had something to refer to if we were unsure about anything - it is such a great new tool for new mums! It was really clear to me that the management in 2 West has done an amazing job and as a result the whole ward is so patient centred and works as one big team. I do wish my experience with my previous birth a couple of years ago was as good as this recent one, but I am so glad that this is the care that women will receive from now on. It really is a credit to all of the staff in Delivery, theatre and 2 West.  
Thank-you!!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Wonderful practice
body:
This practice has always been very good. But over the last two years of Covid they have been exceptional. Working under great pressure they have looked after me and my family so well. Also there is great kindness from all the staff which means a lot.
S F Stephenson

title: Very good practice ..glad i swapped
body: Everyone that works at the practice is warm friendly & very professional....Patience & a smile can be very calming to children & the elderly

title: You are doing a great job
body:
I've just heard about you review findings.  I'd like to say I think you are doing a great job under very difficult circumstances. My Green Light Laser Surgery was very successful and I was looked after by what I consider to be a highly dedicated and caring staff.  I have a hernia operation scheduled for next week within the timescale given.  I have always been treated with the utmost courtesy and support and I'd like this recording.  I have no love for, or faith in, Ofsted (you can delete this last bit if you want).  Keep up the good work you deserve praise rather than criticism and I for one am sorry you have been downgraded - and, in my view, unjustly so.

Dr Clive Opie BSc, PGCE, PFHEA

readBy.name: Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: cygnusgh55
title: Virtual visiting has been a lifeline
body: Both my sister and myself were very disturbed as she had a bad fall. We had one visit the day after she was admitted to C.A.H but none since she was transferred to Loane House. The virtual visiting has been a life line, is a wonderful service and thanks to all who operate it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Female GP
body: 22nd in the phone que and 1hour 32 minutes later i was lucky to get the last appointment of the day. arrived at surgery 5 minutes before my appointment 45 minutes later i went in to see what turned out to be an absolutely amazing female doctor she was polite, listened, and was very understanding and did not try and rush me through my appointment. i wish to say to her thankyou so much.

title: Super friendly
body: Cannot thank the staff enough for their patience and support. Very welcoming on arrival and throughout visit.
